data.text: Contents
Pre-operative assessment and prophylactic anti-emetic plan......................................6

Appendix 1: Broomfield Hospital Algorithm for pre-operative assessment for PONV and prophylactic anti-emetic regime ......................................................................................... 10
Appendix 2: Pharmacological considerations for anti-emetic prophylaxis .......................... 11
Post-operative nausea and vomiting (PONV) can be defined as ‘nausea and vomiting that occurs within the first 24 hours after surgery'. The guideline has
been developed to assist in the management of patients, who are  years or
older at risk of / or experiencing PONV.
PONV is a common complication following surgery. It has been associated

with physiological and psychological effects which can cause delayed recovery after surgery. PONV may directly cause airway compromise, aspiration pneumonia, fluid depletion and electrolyte imbalance, oesophageal rupture, venous hypertension,
increased stress to the patient's wound, which may lead to wound dehiscence, even loss of vision in patients following ophthalmic surgery. Also it can cause fatigue, low mood, distress, and pain.

The guideline is intended to be used to identify patients, aged 16 years and older, who are at risk of / or who are experiencing PONV. It can be used to formulate a prophylactic anti-emetic plan, and provides guidance for active treatment of PONV post-operatively. It can be used by medical and nursing staff.
All qualified nursing and medical staff have individual responsibility to practice within these guidelines.
Ward and Unit managers are responsible for ensuring availability of the guidelines and to facilitate training when required.
IPMS is responsible for ensuring current evidence based review of guidelines and to provide training and education.

PONV can be caused by a number of factors. Opioids are not the only cause for PONV. The 2 main areas that are activated to cause PONV are the Medulla Oblongata and the Chemoreceptor Trigger Zone (CTZ). Nausea and vomiting is under the control of the Central Nervous System (CNS) via the vomiting centre in the Medulla Oblongata and the CTZ in the floor of the th ventricle. See below.
The medulla can be stimulated by the pharyngeal, vagal, and midbrain afferent nerves and by the limbic system.
5.2.1 Pharyngeal / gag reflex can be stimulated by mechanical irritations, for example, by the insertion of a naso-gastric tube, laryngeal mask airway, or endotracheal tube airway.

5.2.2 The vagal afferent nerves can be stimulated by intubation, suctioning that irritates the carina, from noxious substances in the duodenum or stomach, and/or distention / contraction of the gastrointestinal tract.
5.2.3 The midbrain afferents can be stimulated by anaesthesia alone, but also if there is a change in intracranial pressure in the case of neurological procedures.

5.2.4 The limbic system, involved in the emotional processing, can be activated by the learned response of anticipatory vomiting. Pre-emptive anxiolysis with benzodiazepines has shown to help this group of patients; other strategies involve increasing patient information, having vomit receptacles close to the patient post – operatively.

5.2.5 The CTZ sits outside the blood-brain barrier and contains several different receptors. It lies in the Postrema on the floor of the th ventricle and contains multiple receptor sites that may activate emetic responses.

5.2.6 CTZ receptors include Dopamine type 2, Serotonin type 3 (5-HT3), Histamine type 1, muscarinic cholinergic type 1, and Neurokinin type  Blocking these receptors forms the basis of pharmacological interventions. This is why a multi-modal anti- emetic regime is suggested.
5.2.7 The CTZ can also be triggered by the vestibular nerve, when extremes in motion, pressure is applied. Positioning peri-operatively and the length of procedure may cause this activation.
Opioids and other agents can activate the parasympathetic nervous system, delaying GI motility, which may lead to nausea and vomiting.

Cytokines are inevitably released post-surgery which will trigger the release of tachykinins such as Substance P (which are involved in the transmission of pain and nausea). Concentration of receptors for this neuropeptide (neurokinin type 1) is high in the vomiting centre.
Relative hypovolaemia and dehydration associated with pre-op fasting and bowel preparation also contribute to PONV. Adequate hydration pre- operatively will reduce PONV.
Diagram 1: The different pathophysiology involved in nausea and vomiting.

Predicting the occurrence of PONV can be made. A simplified risk score for predicting postoperative nausea and vomiting was formulated by Apfel et al in This has been validated several times since and is the best predictive tool at present.
Risk Assessment tool used to predict likelihood of Patient PONV

table_items.text: Risk Factor (each risk factor carries 1 point)

data.text: Using Apfel's risk assessment tool, the level of risk can be quantified. Low risk patients score 0-1, where there is a 10 to 20% possibility of them experiencing PONV. Moderate risk patients score 2, where there is a 40% possibility of this group experiencing PONV, and High Risk patients score 3- 4, their potential to experience PONV lies between  to 80%.
All patients should be prescribed a structured prophylactic anti-emetic regime, by their anaesthetist.

Additional research concludes that the use of Intra-operative volatile anaesthetics, the use of nitrous oxide, the use of large doses of Neostigmine, and the inclusion of intra-operative opioids may further increase the risk of PONV.
The PONV Risk Assessment should be carried out on all patients who are to undergo surgery.
Pre-operative assessment and prophylactic anti-emetic algorithm
Appendix : MEHT Algorithm for pre-operative assessment for PONV and prophylactic anti-emetic regime
Appendix 2: Pharmacological considerations for anti-emetic prophylaxis
Appendix : MEHT algorithm for the Treatment of Post-operative Nausea and vomiting

Trust policy for prevention of cross infection to be adhered to for all patient contact  procedures. The infection prevention practice within Broomfield Hospital is for all  staff to have strict hand hygiene before and after patient contact. Any equipment  must be cleaned between patients unless it is a single use item which will be  disposed off appropriately as per the Waste Management Policy
Use Aseptic Non-Touch Technique (ANTT) when administering injections.
This guideline is provided for use by trained nurses and medical staff involved in the care of patients at risk from PONV. It also provides evidence-based guidance for trust pharmacists.
Medical staff are expected to understand the need for the assessment of PONV and the clinical importance of treating this promptly and safely.
Training and education is provided by the IPMS, both formally and informally
for all clinical staff. The IPMS is available for advice and consultation via the
pager system, and through the Lorenzo referral system.
Medical staff will be informed of revised guidelines via senior medical staff within the IPMS at audit meetings and twice yearly teaching sessions for all FY1 and FY2 doctors.
Corporate services will ensure that the guideline is uploaded to the intranet
and the website and notified to staff via the staff intranet.
Spot audit of practice in PONV is carried out by the pain team yearly.
All major surgery patients receiving an intravenous morphine PCA or epidural analgesia are reviewed and evaluated for PONV by the pain team.
A teaching programme for both medical and nursing staff is undertaken in liaison with the Training and Development department, which incorporates this subject.
A link pharmacist for the pain team monitors prescribing of antiemetics on all surgical wards, and feeds back at pain team meetings

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Pain Service meeting which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Pain Service Team of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 4)

(2011) ‘PONV-Recommendations for risk assessment, prophylaxis and therapy – results of an expert panel' Epub March 46(3) pp158-70.

Appendix 1: Broomfield Hospital Algorithm for pre-operative assessment for PONV and prophylactic anti-emetic algorithm
Risk Assessment carried out
Inform Anaesthetist, Surgical Team prior to surgery, and at the point of handover to Theatres patients who score a moderate to high risk of PONV

table_items.text: Where vomiting may cause increased risk of surgical complications post op, an extra point may be added to the total PONV risk score. For example, intracranial surgery, intraocular surgery, where patients jaw is wired, etc.

data.text: For patients at Low risk no prophylactic regime is necessary, unless vomiting  For patients at Moderate to high risk a may cause risk of surgical complications (see above)  prophylactic regime is advised. This is the
anaesthetists' decision.
Anaesthetic considerations
Length / type of surgery
Regional anaesthesia  Pharmacological
Use of total IV anaesthesia (TIVA) with Propofol  considerations
Adequate hydration, especially with colloids
Use of intraoperative supplemental Oxygen    Prior to induction
Reduce / avoid use of volatile anaesthetics    On induction
Reduce / avoid use of nitrous oxide    End of surgery
Limiting the dose of Neostigmine to 2.5mg in adults    Post-operatively
Multimodal analgesia post op

Appendix 2: Pharmacological considerations for the anti-emetic prophylaxis

table_items.text: Pharmacological considerations for the anti-emetic prophylaxis
Night before up to 4 hours before the end of surgery
Orally. IV cyclizine to be considered if ondansetron is not tolerated or contra- indicated but orally is the preferable route.
